Series II: Commissarial Records - Army

scopecontent.p: This series is the largest series of records in the Sheftall Papers containing roughly 2600 documents regarding the commissarial activities of Regiments, Battalions, and Units of the Continental Army of South Carolina and Georgia. This finding guide does not provide a history of each unit. A brief overview of the 1st-4thGeorgia Regiments is below:

blockquote.p: 1stGeorgia Regiment:Commanded from 1776-1780 by Col. L. MacIntosh/Habersham/Rae; Authorized Nov. 1775 as "The Georgia Regiment"; Organized Jan.-Apr. 1776; Redesignated as the 1st Georgia Regiment, July 1776; Captured at Charlestown, May 1780.
2ndGeorgia Regiment:Commanded from 1776-1780 by Cols. Habersham/Elbert; Authorized July 1776; Organized in Fall and Winter 1776; Captured at Charlestown, May 1780; Disbanded Jan. 1781
3rdGeorgia Regiment:Commanded from 1776-1780 by Cols. Screven /Stirk; Authorized July 1776; Organized in Fall and Winter 1776; Captured at Charlestown, May 1780; Disbanded Jan. 1781
4thGeorgia Regiment:Commanded from 1777-1780 by Col. John White; Authorized Feb 1777; Organized in summer & fall 1777; Captured at Charlestown May 1780; Disbanded Jan. 1781
For information regarding the structure of a common Provision Return, please refer to the Scope and Content Note portion of this finding aid.

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Provision Returns for the 1st Regiment and 1st Battalion

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains 134 Provision Returns for either the 1stRegiment or 1stBattalion. Recurring names of officers and non-coms in this subseries are: Shadrack Wright; George Young; John Leduc; George Eimbeck; John Habersham; William Damant; John McIntosh; Francis Harris; Charles Noel Romand de Lisle; Thomas Pickney; John Vanderhorst; Will McIntosh; Henry Harris and Samuel Camp. Several of the Provision Returns are for Officers and Non-Coms stationed at Camp Read's Bluff, Darian, Camp Howe, Camp Antonian Fort, and Fort Tonyn. Some returns include lists of names and numbers of persons provided for.

Subseries II: Provision Returns 2nd Regiment and 2nd Battalion

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains 295 Provision Returns signed to either the 2ndRegiment or the 2ndBattalion. Recurring names of officers and non-coms in this Subseries are: William Damant, Shem Cook, Frederick Schick, John Bard, Robert Howe, Elijah Wood, George Hancock, Francis Moore, Benjamin Porter, Samuel Camp, William Matthews, Elisha Miller, James Hull, William Dell, John Wandin, John Strong, Daniel Roberts, John Cunningham, Shadrack Wright, John Stirk, D.L. Roberts, John Vanderhorst, Abraham Jones, James Hill, Sheftall Sheftall, Samuel Elbert, John Strong, Cornelius Collins, Archibald Adams, and John Clarke. Several Captain's Companies are named including: Wood's, Winfrey's, Smyth's (or Smith), Clarke's and Lane's as well as the First, Fifth and Seventh Companies. Several of the Provision Returns are for Officers and Non-coms stationed at McLeland's Plantation, Camp Howe, Fort Tonyn, and for soldiers heading to Sunbury and Read's Bluff. Some returns include lists of names and numbers of persons provided for.

Subseries III: Provision Returns for the 3rd Regiment and 3rd Battalion

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains 328 Provision Returns signed to either the 3rdRegiment or the 3rdBattalion. A partial list of recurring names of officers and non-coms in this Subseries are: John Stirk, Joseph Lane, Robert Howe, John Frazer, Nathaniel Pearce, Thomas Threadgill, Shem Cook, John Peter Wagon [Wagnon], Robert Rae, Charles Clarke, James Scriven, John Jeter, Daniel Roberts, Thomas Lane, John McIntosh, William Lowe, John Dumouchel, Rains Cook, Josiah Hatton, John Phillips, William Scott, Shadrack Wright, James Walton, Thomas Davenport, William Wash, John Walton, Thomas Phillips, William Wash, Gideon Booker, Isaac Hicks, and the mark of Molly Johnston. Captain's companies represented by name are Lane's, Smith's, Scott's, Nash's and Downman's, while the Eighth and Vacant Companies are also mentioned by name. Several of the Provision Returns are for Officers and Non-Coms stationed at Captain Read's Plantation (Read's Bluff), Fort Howe, and men going to Sunbury. Some returns include lists of names and numbers of persons provided for. Several unnamed subaltern soldiers, washerwomen, men, and children are also mentioned in many of the Provision Returns for the 3rdRegiment and 3rdBattalion.

Subseries IV: Provision Returns for the 4th Regiment and 4th Battalion

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains 239 Provision Returns signed to either the 4thRegiment or the 4thBattalion. A partial list of recurring names of officers and non-coms in this Subseries are: John Bard, John White, Matt W. Kinnie, Robert Ellice, Henry Phillips, Celeron Brossard, Christopher Hillary, Thomas Washington, Sheftall Sheftall, Mordecai Sheftall, Shadrack Wright, William Routledge, George Young, George Eastmad, Arthur Hayes, Augustin Despelthiere, Patrick Fitzpatrick, John Bennis, John Caswell, John Ducoin, Phillip Lowe, Bernard Patty, Joseph Day, George Melvern, Joseph Parnell, Phil McDonagh (McDonagel) and Patrick Fitzpatrick. Marie DeBorde and Catherine Tyrall also are mentioned in the Provision Returns. Specific Captain's companies are not mentioned for the most part, while Tybee Island, Fort Tonyn, and Sunbury are a few places mentioned in this set of Provision Returns. Several unnamed subaltern soldiers, washerwomen, men, children and Negroes are also mentioned in many of the Provision Returns for the 4thRegiment and the 4thBattalion.

Subseries V: Provision Returns, Signed-Only, Illegible and Fragmented

scopecontent.p: The Provision Returns for this Subseries contains 363 Provision Returns that do not carry a specifically-named Regiment, Battalion, or Unit, and are either endorsed by signatures or are illegible or fragmented Provision Returns. A few Provision Returns do carry named companies (the Second and Sixth Companies and Colonel Bull's Regiment), but on the whole, regiments, battalions, or units are not noted on the returns. A partial list of recurring names of officers and non-coms in this Subseries are: John Grimké, Charles Noel de Lisle, Peter Taarling, John Vanderhorst, Benjamin Porter, Samuel Camp, Robert Howe, Francis Moore, Matt W. Kinnie, Celeron Brossard, John Wereat, Robert Rae, Samuel Elbert, Samuel Stirk, Laban Johns, George Young, John Habersham, William Dell, William Damant, John McIntosh, John Sutcliffe, Joseph Day, John Wandin, John Girardeau, John Leduc, Joseph Wood, John Bard, Robert Ellice, Francis Harris, Rains Cook, Benjamin Porter, John Strong, William Wash, and names one of the few blacks found in the collection, "the Negro April." Fort Howe, Fort Tonyn, the Camp at Midway and Santilla, Sunbury, and a "small vessel arriving from New Orleans in the Continental Service" are places named within the Provision Returns. Some Provision Returns contain lists of Officers and Non-Coms provided for.

Subseries VI: Provision Returns for the South Carolina Regiments, Battalions, and Units

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains thirty-five Provision Returns specifically naming South Carolina Regiments, Battalions, and Units. A partial list of names from the Provision Returns are: John Vanderhorst, John Harrison, Peter Horn, Shem Cook, William Henderson, James Parham, Hugh Milling, John Detraville, Thomas Pickney, and Charles Warley. Many of the Provision Returns have illegible names recorded on the returns. South Carolina regiments and units specifically named are: the 6thRegiment, the 3rdRegiment and 3rdBattalion, the 2ndBrigade, the 2ndBattalion, the 2ndRegiment, the Artillery Detachment, and the 1stRegiment and 1stBattalion. Fort Howe and St. Catherine's Island are the only two named places within these South Carolina-specified Provision Returns.

Subseries VII: Provision Returns for Multiple Battalions

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains eight Provision Returns with several Battalions named or both Georgia and South Carolina Brigades mentioned. Names include George St. George, Francis Moore and John Manley. Three Provision Returns (#4-#6) are "Lists of Provision Numbers for Georgia and South Carolina Brigades and Other Position Provided For."

Subseries VIII: Provision Returns for the Artificers

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains thirty-three Provision Returns for the Artificer Unit of the Continental Army of Georgia. This unit was in charge of constructing and maintaining arms for the military. The term is of British origin. These Provision Returns are primarily for the 3rdRegiment and 3rdBattalion. (See also Subseries III of the Series for more 3rdRegiment and 3rdBattalion Provision Returns.) Among those who signed the returns are: John Sutcliffe, Peter Taarling, John Peter Wagon, Gideon Booker, David Rainie, Thomas Booker, John Manley, Thomas Threadgill, John Wandin, John Phillips, John McIntosh, Thomas Lane, William Scott, Isaac Hicks and Robert Howe. One Provision Return specifically mentions canteen makers (#3). No specific places are mentioned in these returns.

Subseries IX: Provision Returns for the Artillery

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains 212 Provision Returns for the Artillery Unit of the Continental Army of Georgia, primarily signed by Charles Noel Romand de Lisle. De Lisle was a French Captain who came to America with the Lafayette Expedition. He was made Major of the Artillery by George Washington and served from 1776 to 1778. Names appearing among these Provision Returns are: Thomas Sutton, George Young, Will Johnston, James Alexander, Shadrack Wright, Francis Huger, Saban Johnston, Andrew McFarland, John Francis Detrevillie, Thomas Wright, John Tweedel, Elijah Wilson, Andrew McFarland, Richard [Rick] Watkins, Charles Murrino, James Cherry, Chris Hillary, Andrew Templeton, John Mason, George St. George, John Wandin, and "Capt. Defau." Companies specifically mentioned are the First Continental Artillery Company, the "Late Capt. Lee's First Company of Artillery," the Third Artillery, the 1stBattalion, the 5thSouth Carolina, and the Artillery Fatigue Company. Savannah, Tybee Island, Fort Howe, and Read's Bluff are places mentioned in the returns. One Provision Return provides for the Artillery and Wagoners (#74) and several returns contain lists of those provided for.

Subseries X: Provision Returns for the Barrack Master

scopecontent.p: Subseries X contains twenty-two Provision Returns signed for Barrack Master or Barracks, all of which are signed by the Barrack Master, George Eimbeck. Provision Returns #1 and #2 are also signed by Quartermaster Peter Taarling and the first return mentions the Camp at Fort Howe.

Subseries XI: Provision Returns for the Cattle Guard, Drovers, Forage Master

scopecontent.p: Subseries XI contains thirty-two Provision Returns for the Cattle Guards, Drovers, and Forage Master. One Provision Return (#3) specifically is for the "Forage Company of Ja. Mitchelson, Coms'y of Forage, to Draw 1½ Bushels of Salt for Army Horses." Other signatures include George Caldwell, William Turner, Abraham Jones, and John Vanderhorst. Fort Tonyn is the only location mentioned among these Provision Returns. Provision Return #11 is signed by William Turner and contains a poetic fragment on the back. The origin of this fragment is unknown. A digitized copy of the return is located in Subgroup II; Series I; Subseries I, Item #1, "Poetic Fragment, undated [Rectoof WPA_A-0295 located on aa-p12-sg02-s01-ss01-001]."

Subseries XII: Provision Returns for the Coopers

scopecontent.p: This small Subseries of two Provision Returns are written to the coopers (barrelmakers) and signed by Peter Taarling and John Sutcliffe. Both of the Provision Returns are indexed in the WPA Guide.

Subseries XIII: Provision Returns for the Grenadiers

scopecontent.p: The sixteen Provision Returns in this subseries are for the Grenadier Company, primarily signed for by Francis Moore, with one each signed for by Thomas Davenport and Benjamin Lloyd. Grenadiers were "specialized soldier(s), first established as a distinct role in the mid-to-late 17thcentury, for the throwing of grenades and sometimes assault operations." 31

Subseries XIV: Provision Returns for the Independent Companies, Militias, and Volunteers

scopecontent.p: Thirty-five Provision Returns written for various independent military companies, militias, and volunteers are included in this subseries. The companies named are: the Militia, Capt. Allen's Company of Independent Volunteers, the Independent Companies of State Troops (possibly Capt. Allen's company), Capt. Baker's Volunteers, the True Blue Company, the Cherokee Hill Militia (also called the County of Effingham at Cherokee Hill), Col. Samuel Jack's Battalion, and the South Carolina Militia (Major Shepard's Detachment). Provision Returns are signed by: General Wilder, Moses Allen, William Baker, David Waters, possibly Frederick Roe, John Farley, Abraham Gay, Rick or Rich Quinn, Joseph Dunlap, William Ross, Abraham Ravot, Major Shepheard (also spelled Shepard).

Subseries XV: Provision Returns for the Light Dragoons and Light Infantry

scopecontent.p: Two hundred and ninety-one Provision Returns are included in this Subseries signed to the Light Dragoons, the Light Dragoons and the Light Infantry, and in a few cases, the Light Dragoons of the First Troop. Signatures and names include: Elijah Dickerson, Samuel West, Leonard Marberry, Robert Thompson, Joseph Faulks, Samuel Scott, Shadrack Wright, William Gilmour, Benjamin Walker, Robert Rae, Samuel West, Nicholas Bryson, Hardy Jinkins, John Bilbo, Thomas Claiborne, Arthur Durley, George Bledsoe, John Grimké, Shem Cook, William Johnson, Lee De Keyser, John Bard, James Scott, John Bennis, John Cater, Henry Cannon, James Forman, Moses Wade, Charles Francis Chevalier, Thomas Banks, Parmenas Dawes, and Clement Nash. Some Provision Returns contain lists of those provided for. Please note that Provision Return #291 in this series is out of chronological order due to an Excel glitch that was not caught until after new digital numbers were assigned to the Subseries.

Subseries XVI: Provision Returns for the Magazine and Main Guard

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains one-hundred and forty-eight Provision Returns signed to either the Magazine Guard or the Main Guard, primarily for candles or provisions for prisoners. Signatures and names include: Arthur Hayes, Abraham Jones, Robert Howe, William Strother, Bernard Patty, Nathaniel Pearce, Joshiah Walton, Patrick Fitzpatrick, Edward Cowan, T. Threadgill, Rains Cook, Thomas Washington, Randolph Smith, John Dumochel, James Hull, Wilson McDavies, Samuel Elbert, Frederick Shick, William McDaniel, Frederick Tunnell, Henry Allison, Shadrack Wright, John Morrison, John Clarke, John Wandin, Robert Mosby, Samuel Camp, James Hill and Samuel Jones. Provision Return #84 in this Subseries specifically notes that the provisions are for prisoners of war from theH.M.S. Hichenbrook, written on August 7, 1778.

Subseries XVII: Provision Returns for the Sick and Hospital

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains two-hundred and fifty-nine Provision Returns, many of which list those who are Sick, Very Sick, and Recovered. These Provision Returns are for various Regiments, Battalions and Units, and were culled from their original order if they were written specifically for "the Sick of… ," "the Hospital," "the Use of the Hospital," "Thunderbolt Hospital," and "the sick of the Galleys." If the Regiment, Battalion or Unit is mentioned in the Provision Return, it is included in the Item Title Description. Many of the returns are signed by Surgeon David Brydie. In five cases, Provision Returns signed by Brydie are not included in this Subseries. They are from the 2nd Battalion (Subgroup II, Series II, Subseries II), Provision Returns #92, #98, #124, #129, and #137, as well as Provision Return #13 from the Signed-Only/Unsigned/Illegible/Fragment (Subgroup II, Series II, Subseries V) subseries. These returns are signed by or for Brydie but do not mention the hospital or sick, and are not included in Subseries XVI.

Among the signatures and names for these returns are: David Brydie, Shadrack Wright, Charles Noel Romand de Lisle, John Peter Wagon, surgeon Matt W. Kinnie, Shem Cook, Burrel Smith, Henry Phillips, Doctor Tetard, William Matthews, nurse and wife of David Brydie, Martha; Chris Hillary, Joseph Habersham, Francis Harris, John Stirk, James Houston, John McIntosh, Thomas Davenport, William Dell, Ebenezer Callendar, John Stirk, Oliver Bowen, Andre Smith, Christopher Metz, John Leduc, John Cater, the mark of Peter Ritter, John Phillips, John Adam Alexander, Gideon Booker, Thomas Lane, John Bard, Rains Cook, Isaac Hicks, William Scott, Robert Ellice, and William Dunlap. Please note that this does not include lists of the sick and recovering soldiers that are included in many of these Provision Returns.

Subseries XVIII: Provision Returns for the Wagoners, Georgia and Georgia and South Carolina

scopecontent.p: The last two Subseries of this Subgroup contain Provision Returns for the Wagoners or as they are called within the collection,Wagoners. In regards to Subseries XVIII, the returns are signed to either the Wagoners of Georgia itself, or to the Wagoners of both Georgia and South Carolina combined. Subseries XIX holds Provision Returns for the Wagoners of South Carolina only.

This Subseries contains one-hundred and seventy-four Provision Returns. Names and signatures among this Subseries are: John Wandin, Will Robinson, Joseph Carr, Shadrack Wright, John Leduc, Robert Harrison, James Mitchelson, William Matthews, William Damant, Peter Damant, William Dell, John Sutcliffe, Patrick Stikes, Peter Horn, Joseph Carr, James McCallion, John Burgess, James Cheery, and George Young. The majority of Provision Returns are signed by James Mitchelson, the Conductor of Wagons.

Subseries XIX: Provision Returns for the Wagoners, South Carolina

scopecontent.p: The last two Subseries of this Subgroup contain Provision Returns for the Wagoners. In regards to this Subseries, the returns are for the Wagoners of South Carolina only, while Subseries XVIII are returns signed to either the Wagoners of Georgia itself, or to the Wagoners of both Georgia and South Carolina combined on one Provision Return.

This Subseries contains thirty-two Provision Returns. The primary name that appears in this Subseries is Will Robinson, while other returns are signed by John Wandin, Peter Horn, John Burgess, and John Leduc. Colonel Huger's Wagon Company is mentioned on a few returns.

Series III: Commissarial Records - Naval

scopecontent.p: This Series contains Provision Returns for the four Galleys commissioned by the Continental Congress which made up the Georgia Navy during the American Revolution: theBulloch(Subseries I), theCongress(Subseries II), theWashington(Subseries III), and theLee(Subseries V) Galleys. Also included are Provision Returns for smaller ships, including sloops and flatboats. Of special note are Provision Returns that mention John Newdigate, a captain that figures prominently in several of the ship records in the American Jewish Historical Society's collection of papers fromAaron Lopez (P-11), a merchant from Newport, Rhode Island during the middle 18thcentury.

The WPA Guide to the Sheftall Papers contains an excerpt fromThe Navy and the American Revolution, by Charles Oscar Paullin, 32 which discusses the brief history of the Georgia Navy during the American Revolution. According to Paullin, the Continental Congress resolved in favor of a navy for Georgia on July 5, 1776, under the direction of the Georgia Provincial Congress. This naval force was used primarily to back army actions. Captain Oliver Bowen was ordered to head to Hispaniola to purchase vessels and supplies to arm and outfit a coastal unit. By Spring 1777, "Georgia had three galleys in service, and later, a fourth. These were named theWashington,Lee,Bulloch, andCongress. The little fleet was placed under the command of Commodore Oliver Bowen, and it was employed on the Georgia seacoast chiefly in conjunction with the Army… three of the galleys… assisted the army in its unsuccessful expedition against East Florida in April and May 1777… In April 1778, off Frederica, Georgia, theWashington…Lee… andBulloch… captured his Majesty's brigantine,Hinchenbrooke… and the sloopRebecca." One Provision Return in this collection directly mentions theHinchenbrookeby name, in the Main Guard Subseries, Provision Return #84: for the Main Guard Signed by Samuel Elbert for Daily Provisions to Eight Prisoners of [War] Taken in the [HMS Hinchinbrook] on Their Producing Order for the Same Signed by the Officer of the Main Guard, 08/07/1778 [Indexed #030; 034]. As a point of note, there were two ships used in the American Revolution namedCongress. The first ship was Benedict Arnold's flagship. 33

Early in 1779, as the Battle for Savannah escalated and was ultimately lost by the Continentals, the four Galleys were lost, either burned by the crew to evade capture by the British (WashingtonandBulloch) or abandoned after losing encounters (CongressandLee). When Georgia fell to the British, naval operations in the South ceased.

Other Provision Returns in this Subseries are for smaller boats, other galleys and schooners, observation boats, one or more vessels on the same return, or unknown vessels. Provision Returns for the Sick of the Galleys are included in Subgroup II, Series II, Subseries XVII: Provision Returns for the Sick and Hospital, undated, 1778

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Provision Returns for theBullochGalley

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains sixteen Provision Returns specifically regarding theBullochgalley. The galley was authorized by the Continental Congress on July 5, 1776 under the direction of the Georgia Provincial Congress. It was set on fire by its crew in 1779 to evade capture by the British. Names in this Subseries include Oliver Bowen, John Newdigate, and Archibald Hatchett. Several Provision Returns include short lists of persons provided for.

Subseries II: Provision Returns for theCongressGalley

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains thirty-seven Provision Returns specifically regarding theCongressgalley. The galley was authorized by the Continental Congress on July 5, 1776 under the direction of the Georgia Provincial Congress. The ship was lost to the British during a battle on the Savannah River in March 1779. Names included in this Subseries include: John Newdigate, Lew Mumford (clerk), Oliver Bowen, Samuel Watson, Peter Taarling, Robert Howe, James Farquharson, Solomon Carpenter and John Hardy. Several Provision Returns include small lists of persons provided for.

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains nineteen Provision Returns specifically regarding theWashingtongalley. The galley was authorized by the Continental Congress on July 5, 1776 under the direction of the Georgia Provincial Congress. It was set on fire by its crew in 1779 to evade capture by the British. Names included among the Provision Returns are: Oliver Bowen, John Newdigate, Solomon Carpenter, Samuel Watson, Hull Doty, and James Hardy. Several Provision Returns include small lists of persons provided for.

Subseries V: Provision Returns for Other Vessels

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains forty-five Provision Returns for a variety of vessels whose requisition orders were so few in number as to warrant inclusion into one Subseries. Vessel names are presented in alphabetical order. The ships of varying sizes and types include: the galleys,Beaufort, Lowand the Continental/Georgia Naval vessel, theLee; theColonyboat; theFranklinship; theIrish Villageflat boat (possibly named after a place or group and sometimes simply called, flat or flatt); an unnamed observation boat; the sloopPearl; and the schoonersBeauty,Carolina,Industry,Peggy,RangerandVestra, identified as both a boat and a schooner.

There are six Provision Returns (#25 through #30) specifically regarding theLeegalley, authorized by the Continental Congress on July 5, 1776 under the direction of the Georgia Provincial Congress. The ship was lost to the British during a battle on the Savannah River in March 1779, along with theCongressgalley. Names included in this Subseries are: Oliver Bowen, Francis Lenote, Paul Snyder, John Wandin, John White, George Melvin, John Caswell, John Peter Wagon, Charles Murrina, John Hardy, John Trevor, John Braddock, Thomas Ross, Thomas Sherman, Lyon Henry, Blewet Christopher, John Colley, Robert Spence, and John Wereat.

Subseries VI: Provision Returns for Unknown Vessels

scopecontent.p: The twenty-three Provision Returns in this Subseries are for unnamed ships or were signed by Commodore Oliver Bowen. Other names included on the returns are: John Hardy, John Newdigate, Joseph Feldkellar, Lew Mumford, Paul Snyder, Shadrack Wright, Mrs. Jane Watts, Dr. [Jacob] Blount, John Bridge, John Burgess, Walter Dixon, John Caswell, John Francis de Trevilie, the Boy Peter, and John Wereat.

Provision Return #15 is a Provision Return for the Sick signed by Bowen for molasses to be sent to the sick in Cumberland, Georgia. It was placed in this Suberies and not in Hospital and Sick Returns Subgroup II, Series II, Subseries XVII) because it was signed by Commodore Bowen.

Series IV: Commissarial Ledgers and Account Books

scopecontent.p: Series IV contains commissarial ledgers, account books and loose ledger pages dating primarily from December 1777-December 1778. Subseries I: Account Books and Ledgers, contains somewhat complete accounts of provisions to troops, though they do not account for all of the Provision Returns found in the collection. Subseries II: Individual Ledger Pages, contain pages that could not be traced to existing account books and/or had no original WPA number. Subseries III: Provision Return Unit Covers, were difficult to determine as to their use, but may have been used to divide individual returns.

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Account Books and Ledgers

scopecontent.p: Subseries I: Account Books and Ledgers contain accounts of provisions to troops, though they do not account for all of the Provision Returns found in the collections. Many of the documents in this Subseries are indexed in the WPA Guide to the collection. Included is an account of expenditures for cash paid on account of the Commissary of Purchases, Robert Walton; an account delivery book for back rations; ledgers for miscellaneous expenditures and deliveries; an account book regarding prisoners of war and a "supernumerary book for Samuel Elbert."

Subgroup III: Works Progress Administration Guide and Index

scopecontent.p: The last Subgroup holds two Subseries including the unfinished manuscript index to the collection. The official title to the volume is: "The Sheftall Papers in the Collection of the American Jewish Historical Society: Transcriptions, Excerpts and Lists of Revolutionary Soldiers and Others. Prepared by The Historical Records Survey Division of Community Service Programs, Works Projects Administration, New York, 1941 (Received July 15, 1942)." There are three copies of the volume in varying degrees of completeness, but no copy is finished. Only the most complete guide has been microfilmed and digitized, while two other copies are located within the archival collection. The second portion of the Subgroup holds a collection of Index Cards with original handwritten notes on persons found within the collection. The notes on these cards were transferred to Part II of the WPA Guide,Analytical Indexes to the Sheftall Papers: Persons.

did.unittitle: Series I: Works Progress Administration Guide

scopecontent.p: The volume is made up of several parts, including an unfinished outline introduction that would have explained what the Sheftall papers are, the historical background of the papers, evaluation of the uses of the papers, and acknowledgements.

p.emph: Works Progress Administration Guide, 1941, Part I

scopecontent.p: Part Icontains full or partial transcripts of 328 sample documents from within the collection. The WPA gave each document within the 3,000-plus page collection a code as described in the "Collection and Works Progress Administration Guide Note" section of this finding aid. Each document presented in the WPA Guide was assigned an additional number from 1-328 appearing in [parentheses] next to its WPA Guide code, i.e, [G-329] [328]. Index numbers 194-213 belong to Continental paper money correlating to WPA numbers G-0102 to G-0361 and are no longer in the Sheftall collection.

Part Idivides the collection somewhat into the following series: Commissarial Activities of Mordecai Sheftall (with subseries divisions of Credentials and Instructions; Record of Supplies; Account with United States and Georgia); Mercantile Ledger; Continental Paper Money (the actual paper money is missing from the American Jewish Historical Society's collection); Private Papers for the SchoonerHetty; and Sheftall Family Letters and Papers. Please note that documents do not necessarily appear in their original placement within the WPA collection.

To maintain consistency between the WPA Guide and the newly microfilmed and digitized collection, each document appearing in the WPA Guide was located and its index number recorded: on the document itself, an asterisk appears next to the WPA Code; the Index Number and WPA Code is noted next to each document's description in the finding aid; the Index Number is retained in each document's metadata and appears in the Master Excel Sheet for the collection as well.

Note: Some items were not attached to their storage paper backings and subsequently lost their identifying WPA code number. Among these items is a 28-page Memorandum Book for theCongressgalley with the Index #144 linked to document WPA_A-0011 as well as [WPA_A-0001 Index #150] [WPA_A-0006 Index #155] [WPA_A-0006 Index #156] [WPA_A-0007 Index #159]. Index #160 in the original WPA guide had no WPA code assigned to the document.

Commissarial Activities: Credentials and Instructions(index numbers 1-4) lists documents pertaining to the appointment of Mordecai Sheftall as Commissary of Issues.Commissarial Activities: Record of Supplies(index numbers 5-160) lists documents which recorded sample types of Provision Returns, unusual Provision Returns and Ration Books, and a summary of ration books, ledgers, and journals.Commissarial Activities: Account with United States and Georgia(index numbers 161-165) lists documents regarding cash vouchers and claims against the United States and Georgia filed by Mordecai Sheftall.

Mercantile Ledger(index numbers 166-193) outlines Mordecai Sheftall's shipping and business accounting from August 8, 1783 to January 13, 1794.Continental Paper Money(index numbers 194-213) outlined printed money and certificates with serial numbers and handwritten signatures that appeared in the collection at one time. This collection of Continental money is not available at the American Jewish Historical Society and AJHS documentation regarding what happened to the certificates is unknown.

Privateer Papers: Schooner Hetty(index numbers 214-251) contains transcripts of correspondence between Sheftall and Hetty captains Henry Darnal and Thomas DeBurk regarding the workings and tribulations of theHettyfrom 1781-1782. Also included are receipts for crew payments, a manifest of crew signatures, bills for goods purchased for the ship, a sales ledger, prize money receipts, and other items. The final portion of the WPA Guide regarding the collection isSheftall Family Letters and Papers(index numbers 252-328). This part of the guide outlines most of the personal family papers found in the collection dealing directly with the Sheftalls: Mordecai, Frances, Sheftall Benjamin, and Moses, mostly in the form of correspondence.

p.emph: Part II: Works Progress Administration Guide, 1941

scopecontent.p: Part IIof the WPA Guide,Analytical Indexes to the Sheftall Papers, contains very helpful lists ofPersons,Places, andShipsnames appearing within the indexed portion of the collection. This section of the WPA Guide is closely related to Series II: Index Cards, undated. The Persons Index lists all persons mentioned in the Sheftall Papers as well as codes linking them to bibliographic sources of American Revolution soldier and participant rolls. According to the introduction to this section, "This alphabetical list contains all of the names, with their variants, found in the Sheftall papers; those in capital letters will be found in the transcriptions and abstracts in Part I of this book."

blockquote.p: "Family names have been corrected only in instances where identification was a certainty; otherwise, names have been scrupulously transcribed. In many instances, only abbreviations of given names were found. Where these were plainly evident, as in the case of Jas. (James), Jos. (Joseph), Sam'l (Samuel), Wm. (William), etc., the complete spelling of has been given. Surname variants have been consolidated, and even then the spelling variants have been included in parentheses. When consolidated, every effort has been made to index under the more acceptable spelling as determined by usage in various published lists.
A cross mark (X) inserted between family and given names indicates the person could not write (from illiteracy or accident) and that he made his mark.
An asterisk (*) indicates that a biographical sketch of the person appears in the Biographical Index.

Following the person's name is the most commonly given rank (military, naval, civilian) and following this, the unit, military and/or naval, with which he was associated. Other ranks and units with which his name appears are enclosed in parentheses.

Military and naval ranks, as well as units, are abbreviated according to Army and Navy usage, with the exceptions that 1GB, 2GB, 3GB, 4GB stand for First, Second, Third, Fourth Georgia Battalions of Continental troops.

Following the units mentioned, we give the first and last dates of papers upon which the name appears. Since practically all ration returns and ledger entries in this collection were written in 1778, the year is omitted when the date-span falls entirely within 1778, for the sake of brevity.

The file box letter and manuscript number of the first and last manuscript dates are given in parentheses. The numbers which appear in brackets between these denote the additional manuscripts in which any given name is found.

Ten additional sources have been consulted for verification of, or additional information on, names of persons in this list. These sources are:
A - British Acts of Attainder
C I, CII, CIII - Candler's Revolutionary Records of Georgia, vols. I, II, III
D - Disqualifying Act
H - Heitman's Official Register
K - Knight's Georgia Roster
O - Officers Not Exchanged
P - Parolee List
R - Revolutionary Soldiers' Receipts
S.C.P. - Sourth Carolina Pension Roll, U.S. War Dept.
W - Prisoners of War
Wil - Wilson's Annals of Georgia
Example to illustrate these rules of interpretation: 34
*BOWEN, Oliver; Commodore; Feb. 20.-Aug. 31 (D323 [74] D388); 54, 61, 63, 88, 90, [A; D; H, Capt., 1GB; K, Son of Liberty, member Provincial Congress, Capt. of galley, Commodore.]

Interpretation: Biographical sketch of Oliver Bowen in biographical Index of this book; his name first appears in this collection under date February 20, 1778, library number D323, last appears under date August 31, 1778, library number D388; appears 74 times between these dates [library has card catalogue for each entry]; his name appears in entries 54, 61, 63, 88, 90 of book; his name appears on British Acts of Attainder and on Disqualifying Act; Heitman lists him as Captain, First Georgia Battalion; Knight lists him as Son of Liberty, member Provincial Congress, Captain of Galley, Commodore."

scopecontent.p: Placeslists camps, forts, counties, islands, rivers, towns, hospitals, plantations, and inns named within the collection papers.Shipslists names barges, boats, brigs, brigantines, corsairs, cutters, flats, gallies, packets, privateers, prices, schooners, shallops and sloops named in the collection.

Series II: Index Cards

scopecontent.p: The final series in this collection is a set of handwritten index cards containing the research used for the People and Places Indexes of the WPA Guide.

did.unittitle: Index Cards
Separated Oversized Material

scopecontent.p: This Oversized documents series contains eight large documents (one of which is missing) and a reference to one document that has been moved to the Gratz Family Papers. Three of the documents are newspapers: theFederal Union(Milledgeville, GA) dated June 20, 1833 (Moses Sheftall Series); theDaily Morning News(Savannah, GA) dated August 28, 1857 (Sheftall Family Papers), and theCentral City(Albany, GA) dated June 12, 1873 (Sheftall Family Papers). The missing newspaper is theSavannah Daily Republicanof October 16, 1858. Also included is a Bill of Indenture for Property in Chatham County, GA, from the Moses Sheftall portion of the papers; a ship's manifest with crew signatures for theHettyand an oversized clipping from a newspaper dated April 10, 1867 regarding Reconstruction and the Supreme Court from the Sheftall family papers.
